Simulink Code Generation Optimization::--Learn to control and optimize how Simulink handles block parameters during code generationâ€”improving efficiency, flexibility, and performance in your generated code.Default Parameter Behaviour (Inlined or Tunable) - This settings controls how numeric block parameters (e.g., constants in Gain blocks) are handled in the generated code.1. Inlined (default for ERT (embedded real time) targets):--Embeds literal numeric values directly in code (means the numbers are hardcoded instead of being defined as variables or parameters. In Simulink (or programming in general), this means typing values like 5, 3.14, or [1 2 3] directly into block parameters)--Pros: Reduces RAM usage, improves execution speed.--Cons: Parameters are not tunable/calibratable post-code generation.--Required for: Models using Embedded CoderÂ® with service interface configurations. (In Embedded Coder, a service interface configuration is a way to generate code that connects your Simulink model to external application softwareâ€”like AUTOSAR components, real-time operating systems (RTOS), or custom embedded systems.)2. Tunable (default for GRT (Generic real time) targets):--Stores parameters in a global structure (can be modified/calibrated post-generation).--Pros: Allows parameter tuning (e.g., for calibration).--Cons: Uses more RAM, slightly slower.hashtag#Simulink hashtag#EmbeddedCoder hashtag#ModelBasedDesign hashtag#CodeGeneration hashtag#MATLAB hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#ControlSystems hashtag#EngineeringTools hashtag#CCodeFromSimulink hashtag#TechDocumentation hashtag#electricvehicles

In the latest blog post by gdotv - Graph Database Client & Visualization Tooling, we can see an interesting Kuzu graph of past talks and events by Connected Data London, as part of the "Connected Data Knowledge Graph Challenge" (CDKG). As you'll see, the graph that's stored in a Kuzu database can be visualized effectively and effortlessly by G.V()! Blog post: https://lnkd.in/gmTZ-ZFEWhy Kuzu? The blog describes how Kuzu is built for speed, and how you can feel it when using it with G.V(). "Queries finish running faster than you can blink. Weâ€™ve sampled quite a few datasets and tried path queries of up to 30 hops, all running at milliseconds scale."âœ… The CDKG graph has the following schema:  Speakers give talks, which have keyword tags (topic of the talk). Each talk is from a past event, and belongs to a particular category.âœ… The power of graph visualization is clear with G.V(). The first image attached shows multiple layouts. The default mode is a "force-directed" layout, which shows clusters of speakers and talk topic keywords around a particular event.âœ… The other image shows a tree layout, where it's immediately obvious, at a glance, which speakers spoke at both events, and which categories have the most talks. The different layouts each showcase different aspects about the data, making it a breeze to explore the data visually for insights.We think Kuzu and G.V() can help you discover many more insights on your own data! If you want to check out the CDKG graph used in this blog post, check out the code and the vision here: https://lnkd.in/dzZBQcp4

Let me introduce you to Hidden Classes, a lesser-known capability added in Java 15 (JEP 371). These are dynamically generated classes that remain invisible to the outside world, meaning theyâ€™re not accessible via standard class loaders. Why Are They Cool?If youâ€™ve worked with frameworks like Spring, Hibernate, or tools relying on dynamic proxies, youâ€™ve likely encountered classes created on the fly. Hidden Classes take this to the next level by allowing frameworks to generate classes at runtime that are:Secure: They canâ€™t be accessed directly outside their defining context.Efficient: They reduce memory overhead by avoiding unnecessary class loading.Clean: They keep the JVMâ€™s namespace tidy by staying hidden.This makes them perfect for:Dynamic Proxy GenerationÂ (e.g., Spring AOP or mock libraries like Mockito).ORM FrameworksÂ (e.g., Hibernate generating proxies for lazy-loaded entities).Reflection-based ToolsÂ (e.g., libraries creating helper classes at runtime).Fun fact: Hibernate has been leveraging Hidden Classes in newer versions to optimize proxy generation, reducing memory footprint for large-scale apps!Why Are They Cool?Hidden Classes shine in performance and security. By keeping dynamically generated classes out of the standard class loader, they prevent accidental (or malicious) access. Plus, theyâ€™re lightweight, which is a win for applications generating thousands of proxies, like a busy Spring Boot app handling millions of requests.Thereâ€™s a catch, though: Hidden Classes are tied to a single JVM instance. You canâ€™t serialize or persist them, so theyâ€™re best for transient, runtime-only tasks.As an example:We use defineHiddenClass (introduced in Java 15) to create a class thatâ€™s hidden from standard class loaders. In real projects, youâ€™d generate bytecode with libraries like ASM or ByteBuddy, which are popular for creating dynamic classes (e.g., Hibernate uses similar techniques for entity proxies).hashtag#Java hashtag#HiddenClasses hashtag#JVM hashtag#Reflection hashtag#Spring hashtag#Hibernate

The key differentiator: how we communicate.Communication is key in people leadership no matter the setting, but remote management and team engagement require more intentional ways of communicating.Why? Itâ€™s easier to lean too heavily on contextless communication. This leaves room for more frequent misunderstandings and communication breakdowns.If the majority of your middle managers learned how to manage in-office but you want to keep the competitive advantage of offering remote or hybrid work, now is a great time to level up their training.Capturing the best talent moving forward will require more flexibility in where work gets done.Retaining that talent will lean heavily on their managerâ€™s ability to foster the right environment for growth and workplace satisfaction.If youâ€™re looking for support up-skilling your middle management team, letâ€™s chat.When middle management is armed with the right skills employee productivity improves as a byproduct. ğŸš€ My Java Journey: From Basics to Building Real-World Applications â˜•âœ¨âœ¨âœ¨Day 40ğŸŒ„ğŸŒ„Using of Final Keyword.... In Java, the final keyword is used to restrict the modification of variables, methods, and classes. There are 3 ways to input in the final keyword.. 3 ways to constext -:-->Final Variable-:A final variable cannot be reassigned after it has been initialized.For objects, final means the reference cannot change, but the object's contents can (unless the object itself is immutable).-->Final Method-:A final method cannot be overridden by subclasses.-->Final Class-:A final class cannot be extended (no subclassing).hashtag#Java hashtag#Coding hashtag#Learning hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Programming hashtag#TechJourney

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)âœ…"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."ğŸŒŸ What is a Package?A package is like a folder in your computer that helps you organize your Java files (classes, interfaces, etc.).ğŸŒŸ Why do we use Packages?To organize code neatlyTo avoid name conflicts (two classes can have the same name if they are in different packages)To reuse code easilyTo make project structure clean and easy to manageğŸŒŸ Types of Packages:Built-in packages â€“ already available in Java (like java.util, java.io)User-defined packages â€“ created by us to group our own classesğŸŒŸ How to Create and Use a Package?You create a package using the package keyword.You use it by importing it with the import keyword.ğŸŒŸ Think of it like this:Your computer has folders (packages)Inside folders, you have files (Java classes)You can open and use files from any folder using the correct path (importing the package)

HOW REMOTE WORK GIVES SMALL BUSINESSES A FIGHTING CHANCE In early 2020 as we contemplated or more like dreaded the idea of having the entire team working remotely, little did we know that remote work would be the silver lining we needed.Sure, we moved on from NGcareers in 2020 (after exiting to ROAM/Jobberman) but the lessons we got from working remotely in 2020 positioned us for our next venture.When we started Remote4Africa there was no question of whether to be a remote company or not. The very nature of Remote4Africa meant we had to live what we preached - full remote operation.SO HOW DOES WORKING REMOTELY FAVOUR THE SMALL GUY? As a small, medium or growing company remote work gives you several advantages. Forget the naysayers and come with me. The two biggest advantages;Bigger Talent Pool As a remote company you are not restricted to just one city in your search for talent to help grow the company. You can literally hire smart young people from across the entire country or even continent (We help companies hire remotely - https://lnkd.in/g5-2qm2p). Your talent pool becomes automatically wider. Greater Cost EfficiencyA startup or small business usually doesnâ€™t have endless money, in fact most struggle financially in the early years until their products/services start to generate significant revenue to outpace expenses. So how do you keep yourself in the game and extend the chances of your business surviving? By keeping expenses as low as possible. Going remote does that for you. We spent millions annually in office rent in Lagos. That was money that could have gone into marketing or direct revenue impacting activity. If you are building/growing a business in any major African city you know office costs are a significant part of your expenses. Aside rent you are talking about utilities, furniture etc.You can take some of that saving and give your remote staff stuff like data allowances, workspace allowances etc to help them set up and work comfortably from home.If you run a company/business and thinking of going remote you can reach out and ask any questions. Iâ€™ll be glad to advise and share lessons from what weâ€™ve learnt running a remote company for 5 years now.hashtag#hiringremote hashtag#remotecompanies hashtag#businesstips hashtag#recruitingtips

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)âœ…"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."ğŸŒŸ What is Exception Handling?Exception handling is a way to manage errors that occur while a program is running. Instead of stopping the entire program when an error happens, exception handling lets you control what should happen when something goes wrong.ğŸŒŸ Why is it important?It helps prevent the program from crashing.It allows the program to continue running even after an error.It shows clear and friendly error messages to the user.It makes debugging and fixing issues easier.ğŸŒŸ How does it work?You write the code that might cause an error inside a special block. If an error happens, another block will handle it. This keeps the program safe and avoids unexpected crashes.ğŸŒŸ Key Terms:Try: The block where you write the code that might cause an error.Catch: The block where you handle the error if it occurs.Finally: A block that runs no matter whatâ€”whether there was an error or not.Throw: Used to create custom errors or exceptions.Throws: Used to declare exceptions that a method might cause.

Today's Learning Journey ğŸ“•: Stacks in JavaToday, I explored one of the fundamental data structuresâ€” the Stack.**What is a Stack?** A Stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle. The last element added is the first one to be removed. Think of it like a stack of plates â€” you add to the top and remove from the top.**Why It's Important?** Stacks are used in many areas like function calls, expression evaluation, undo features in editors, and more. Understanding how they work is essential for solving real-world problems and mastering algorithms.**Key Takeaways:** 1. Core Operations: push(), pop(), peek(), and isEmpty()2. Implementation: Explored Java's built-in Stack class and also implemented it manually using arrays and linked lists. 3. Applications: Helps build intuition for recursion, backtracking, and parsing tasks.hashtag#Java hashtag#DataStructures hashtag#Stack hashtag#CodingJourney hashtag#Programming hashtag#TechLearning

Standardisation of Railway signallingThere Are in principle today 3 ways of interlocking design. 1) free wired2) object oriented3) geographicalSo what defines their adavantages and disadvantages, regading Generic and Specific applications?Engineering: nr 3) provides a high amount of Generic functionality and a little part of specific engineering. Gives the supplier more work at the start, but simplifies all over time. Rating 3-2-1 in quality. Specifying SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Testing SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Resposibilities: testing of SA is typically moved back to the infrastructure manager, where 1) gives a lot of work, while 3) is reduced to a functional level. Bane NOR have chosen 3) to get a high amount of Generic functionality and Standardised Engineering for its National ERTMS L2 system, due to the totality of deliveries. Based on our experience this is the right way to go to limit amount of work and to maximise the level of standardisation of functionality throughout the network, and limits all local variants of today.

We have just published our hashtag#OpenSource hashtag#MATLAB scripts for the complete operation of FLEXT, a custom-built X-ray CT scanner. The scripts connect to a variety of instruments through different communication protocols, making it possible to produce X-ray CT projections of materials. If you are interested in hardware/software interaction with MATLAB, you will find a treasure trove of scripts that interact with various devices from thermocouples and laser distance meters to X-ray sources and X-ray detectors. There is even temperature control software with a proportional-integral control algorithm to maintain a set-point temperature by adjusting the temperature of a heat circulator - entirely in MATLAB (MathWorks).You can find the description of our work here: https://lnkd.in/g9paZ-pPYou can access the software here: https://lnkd.in/gPr55-N8I developed this software at DTU Offshore - Danish Offshore Technology Centre with help from many colleagues, especially Rasoul Mokhtari and Karen Feilberg. Simulink Code Generation Optimization::--Learn to control and optimize how Simulink handles block parameters during code generationâ€”improving efficiency, flexibility, and performance in your generated code.Default Parameter Behaviour (Inlined or Tunable) - This settings controls how numeric block parameters (e.g., constants in Gain blocks) are handled in the generated code.1. Inlined (default for ERT (embedded real time) targets):--Embeds literal numeric values directly in code (means the numbers are hardcoded instead of being defined as variables or parameters. In Simulink (or programming in general), this means typing values like 5, 3.14, or [1 2 3] directly into block parameters)--Pros: Reduces RAM usage, improves execution speed.--Cons: Parameters are not tunable/calibratable post-code generation.--Required for: Models using Embedded CoderÂ® with service interface configurations. (In Embedded Coder, a service interface configuration is a way to generate code that connects your Simulink model to external application softwareâ€”like AUTOSAR components, real-time operating systems (RTOS), or custom embedded systems.)2. Tunable (default for GRT (Generic real time) targets):--Stores parameters in a global structure (can be modified/calibrated post-generation).--Pros: Allows parameter tuning (e.g., for calibration).--Cons: Uses more RAM, slightly slower.hashtag#Simulink hashtag#EmbeddedCoder hashtag#ModelBasedDesign hashtag#CodeGeneration hashtag#MATLAB hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#ControlSystems hashtag#EngineeringTools hashtag#CCodeFromSimulink hashtag#TechDocumentation hashtag#electricvehicles

Each talk is from a past event, and belongs to a particular category.âœ… The power of graph visualization is clear with G.V(). The first image attached shows multiple layouts. The default mode is a "force-directed" layout, which shows clusters of speakers and talk topic keywords around a particular event.âœ… The other image shows a tree layout, where it's immediately obvious, at a glance, which speakers spoke at both events, and which categories have the most talks. Let me introduce you to Hidden Classes, a lesser-known capability added in Java 15 (JEP 371). These are dynamically generated classes that remain invisible to the outside world, meaning theyâ€™re not accessible via standard class loaders. Why Are They Cool?If youâ€™ve worked with frameworks like Spring, Hibernate, or tools relying on dynamic proxies, youâ€™ve likely encountered classes created on the fly. Hidden Classes take this to the next level by allowing frameworks to generate classes at runtime that are:Secure: They canâ€™t be accessed directly outside their defining context.Efficient: They reduce memory overhead by avoiding unnecessary class loading.Clean: They keep the JVMâ€™s namespace tidy by staying hidden.This makes them perfect for:Dynamic Proxy GenerationÂ (e.g., Spring AOP or mock libraries like Mockito).ORM FrameworksÂ (e.g., Hibernate generating proxies for lazy-loaded entities).Reflection-based ToolsÂ (e.g., libraries creating helper classes at runtime).Fun fact: Hibernate has been leveraging Hidden Classes in newer versions to optimize proxy generation, reducing memory footprint for large-scale apps!Why Are They Cool?Hidden Classes shine in performance and security. By keeping dynamically generated classes out of the standard class loader, they prevent accidental (or malicious) access. Plus, theyâ€™re lightweight, which is a win for applications generating thousands of proxies, like a busy Spring Boot app handling millions of requests.Thereâ€™s a catch, though: Hidden Classes are tied to a single JVM instance. You canâ€™t serialize or persist them, so theyâ€™re best for transient, runtime-only tasks.As an example:We use defineHiddenClass (introduced in Java 15) to create a class thatâ€™s hidden from standard class loaders. In real projects, youâ€™d generate bytecode with libraries like ASM or ByteBuddy, which are popular for creating dynamic classes (e.g., Hibernate uses similar techniques for entity proxies).hashtag#Java hashtag#HiddenClasses hashtag#JVM hashtag#Reflection hashtag#Spring hashtag#Hibernate

Disclaimer: This post does not take a stance on in-office versus remote or hybrid work.It does however highlight that management cannot operate the same way in all settings.In my career, I have worked in both in-office and remote settings.Iâ€™ve had to have hard conversations in both settings.Iâ€™ve had to train people in both settings.Iâ€™ve had to build trust and rapport in both settings.Each setting has its own set of nuances. The key differentiator: how we communicate.Communication is key in people leadership no matter the setting, but remote management and team engagement require more intentional ways of communicating.Why? Itâ€™s easier to lean too heavily on contextless communication. This leaves room for more frequent misunderstandings and communication breakdowns.If the majority of your middle managers learned how to manage in-office but you want to keep the competitive advantage of offering remote or hybrid work, now is a great time to level up their training.Capturing the best talent moving forward will require more flexibility in where work gets done.Retaining that talent will lean heavily on their managerâ€™s ability to foster the right environment for growth and workplace satisfaction.If youâ€™re looking for support up-skilling your middle management team, letâ€™s chat.When middle management is armed with the right skills employee productivity improves as a byproduct. So the question is...Do you have a productivity problem or a management problem?hashtag#Remote hashtag#Hybrid hashtag#Management hashtag#Training hashtag#FutureOfWork hashtag#CompetitiveAdvantage hashtag#EmployeeExperience hashtag#EmployeeRetention

In Java, the final keyword is used to restrict the modification of variables, methods, and classes. There are 3 ways to input in the final keyword.. 3 ways to constext -:-->Final Variable-:A final variable cannot be reassigned after it has been initialized.For objects, final means the reference cannot change, but the object's contents can (unless the object itself is immutable).-->Final Method-:A final method cannot be overridden by subclasses.-->Final Class-:A final class cannot be extended (no subclassing).hashtag#Java hashtag#Coding hashtag#Learning hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Programming hashtag#TechJourney

HOW REMOTE WORK GIVES SMALL BUSINESSES A FIGHTING CHANCE In early 2020 as we contemplated or more like dreaded the idea of having the entire team working remotely, little did we know that remote work would be the silver lining we needed.Sure, we moved on from NGcareers in 2020 (after exiting to ROAM/Jobberman) but the lessons we got from working remotely in 2020 positioned us for our next venture.When we started Remote4Africa there was no question of whether to be a remote company or not. The very nature of Remote4Africa meant we had to live what we preached - full remote operation.SO HOW DOES WORKING REMOTELY FAVOUR THE SMALL GUY? As a small, medium or growing company remote work gives you several advantages. Forget the naysayers and come with me. The two biggest advantages;Bigger Talent Pool As a remote company you are not restricted to just one city in your search for talent to help grow the company. You can literally hire smart young people from across the entire country or even continent (We help companies hire remotely - https://lnkd.in/g5-2qm2p). Your talent pool becomes automatically wider. Greater Cost EfficiencyA startup or small business usually doesnâ€™t have endless money, in fact most struggle financially in the early years until their products/services start to generate significant revenue to outpace expenses. So how do you keep yourself in the game and extend the chances of your business surviving? By keeping expenses as low as possible. Going remote does that for you. We spent millions annually in office rent in Lagos. That was money that could have gone into marketing or direct revenue impacting activity. If you are building/growing a business in any major African city you know office costs are a significant part of your expenses. Aside rent you are talking about utilities, furniture etc.You can take some of that saving and give your remote staff stuff like data allowances, workspace allowances etc to help them set up and work comfortably from home.If you run a company/business and thinking of going remote you can reach out and ask any questions. Iâ€™ll be glad to advise and share lessons from what weâ€™ve learnt running a remote company for 5 years now.hashtag#hiringremote hashtag#remotecompanies hashtag#businesstips hashtag#recruitingtips

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)âœ…"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."ğŸŒŸ What is Exception Handling?Exception handling is a way to manage errors that occur while a program is running. Instead of stopping the entire program when an error happens, exception handling lets you control what should happen when something goes wrong.ğŸŒŸ Why is it important?It helps prevent the program from crashing.It allows the program to continue running even after an error.It shows clear and friendly error messages to the user.It makes debugging and fixing issues easier.ğŸŒŸ How does it work?You write the code that might cause an error inside a special block. If an error happens, another block will handle it. This keeps the program safe and avoids unexpected crashes.ğŸŒŸ Key Terms:Try: The block where you write the code that might cause an error.Catch: The block where you handle the error if it occurs.Finally: A block that runs no matter whatâ€”whether there was an error or not.Throw: Used to create custom errors or exceptions.Throws: Used to declare exceptions that a method might cause.

Today's Learning Journey ğŸ“•: Stacks in JavaToday, I explored one of the fundamental data structuresâ€” the Stack.**What is a Stack?** A Stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle. The last element added is the first one to be removed. Think of it like a stack of plates â€” you add to the top and remove from the top.**Why It's Important?** Stacks are used in many areas like function calls, expression evaluation, undo features in editors, and more. Understanding how they work is essential for solving real-world problems and mastering algorithms.**Key Takeaways:** 1. Core Operations: push(), pop(), peek(), and isEmpty()2. Implementation: Explored Java's built-in Stack class and also implemented it manually using arrays and linked lists. 3. Standardisation of Railway signallingThere Are in principle today 3 ways of interlocking design. 1) free wired2) object oriented3) geographicalSo what defines their adavantages and disadvantages, regading Generic and Specific applications?Engineering: nr 3) provides a high amount of Generic functionality and a little part of specific engineering. Gives the supplier more work at the start, but simplifies all over time. Rating 3-2-1 in quality. Specifying SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Testing SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Resposibilities: testing of SA is typically moved back to the infrastructure manager, where 1) gives a lot of work, while 3) is reduced to a functional level. Bane NOR have chosen 3) to get a high amount of Generic functionality and Standardised Engineering for its National ERTMS L2 system, due to the totality of deliveries. Based on our experience this is the right way to go to limit amount of work and to maximise the level of standardisation of functionality throughout the network, and limits all local variants of today.

Simulink Code Generation Optimization::--Learn to control and optimize how Simulink handles block parameters during code generationâ€”improving efficiency, flexibility, and performance in your generated code.Default Parameter Behaviour (Inlined or Tunable) - This settings controls how numeric block parameters (e.g., constants in Gain blocks) are handled in the generated code.1. Inlined (default for ERT (embedded real time) targets):--Embeds literal numeric values directly in code (means the numbers are hardcoded instead of being defined as variables or parameters. In Simulink (or programming in general), this means typing values like 5, 3.14, or [1 2 3] directly into block parameters)--Pros: Reduces RAM usage, improves execution speed.--Cons: Parameters are not tunable/calibratable post-code generation.--Required for: Models using Embedded CoderÂ® with service interface configurations. (In Embedded Coder, a service interface configuration is a way to generate code that connects your Simulink model to external application softwareâ€”like AUTOSAR components, real-time operating systems (RTOS), or custom embedded systems.)2. Tunable (default for GRT (Generic real time) targets):--Stores parameters in a global structure (can be modified/calibrated post-generation).--Pros: Allows parameter tuning (e.g., for calibration).--Cons: Uses more RAM, slightly slower.hashtag#Simulink hashtag#EmbeddedCoder hashtag#ModelBasedDesign hashtag#CodeGeneration hashtag#MATLAB hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#ControlSystems hashtag#EngineeringTools hashtag#CCodeFromSimulink hashtag#TechDocumentation hashtag#electricvehicles

Let me introduce you to Hidden Classes, a lesser-known capability added in Java 15 (JEP 371). These are dynamically generated classes that remain invisible to the outside world, meaning theyâ€™re not accessible via standard class loaders. Why Are They Cool?If youâ€™ve worked with frameworks like Spring, Hibernate, or tools relying on dynamic proxies, youâ€™ve likely encountered classes created on the fly. Hidden Classes take this to the next level by allowing frameworks to generate classes at runtime that are:Secure: They canâ€™t be accessed directly outside their defining context.Efficient: They reduce memory overhead by avoiding unnecessary class loading.Clean: They keep the JVMâ€™s namespace tidy by staying hidden.This makes them perfect for:Dynamic Proxy GenerationÂ (e.g., Spring AOP or mock libraries like Mockito).ORM FrameworksÂ (e.g., Hibernate generating proxies for lazy-loaded entities).Reflection-based ToolsÂ (e.g., libraries creating helper classes at runtime).Fun fact: Hibernate has been leveraging Hidden Classes in newer versions to optimize proxy generation, reducing memory footprint for large-scale apps!Why Are They Cool?Hidden Classes shine in performance and security. By keeping dynamically generated classes out of the standard class loader, they prevent accidental (or malicious) access. Plus, theyâ€™re lightweight, which is a win for applications generating thousands of proxies, like a busy Spring Boot app handling millions of requests.Thereâ€™s a catch, though: Hidden Classes are tied to a single JVM instance. You canâ€™t serialize or persist them, so theyâ€™re best for transient, runtime-only tasks.As an example:We use defineHiddenClass (introduced in Java 15) to create a class thatâ€™s hidden from standard class loaders. In real projects, youâ€™d generate bytecode with libraries like ASM or ByteBuddy, which are popular for creating dynamic classes (e.g., Hibernate uses similar techniques for entity proxies).hashtag#Java hashtag#HiddenClasses hashtag#JVM hashtag#Reflection hashtag#Spring hashtag#Hibernate

In Java, the final keyword is used to restrict the modification of variables, methods, and classes. There are 3 ways to input in the final keyword.. 3 ways to constext -:-->Final Variable-:A final variable cannot be reassigned after it has been initialized.For objects, final means the reference cannot change, but the object's contents can (unless the object itself is immutable).-->Final Method-:A final method cannot be overridden by subclasses.-->Final Class-:A final class cannot be extended (no subclassing).hashtag#Java hashtag#Coding hashtag#Learning hashtag#SoftwareDevelopment hashtag#Programming hashtag#TechJourney

HOW REMOTE WORK GIVES SMALL BUSINESSES A FIGHTING CHANCE In early 2020 as we contemplated or more like dreaded the idea of having the entire team working remotely, little did we know that remote work would be the silver lining we needed.Sure, we moved on from NGcareers in 2020 (after exiting to ROAM/Jobberman) but the lessons we got from working remotely in 2020 positioned us for our next venture.When we started Remote4Africa there was no question of whether to be a remote company or not. The very nature of Remote4Africa meant we had to live what we preached - full remote operation.SO HOW DOES WORKING REMOTELY FAVOUR THE SMALL GUY? As a small, medium or growing company remote work gives you several advantages. Forget the naysayers and come with me. The two biggest advantages;Bigger Talent Pool As a remote company you are not restricted to just one city in your search for talent to help grow the company. You can literally hire smart young people from across the entire country or even continent (We help companies hire remotely - https://lnkd.in/g5-2qm2p). Your talent pool becomes automatically wider. Greater Cost EfficiencyA startup or small business usually doesnâ€™t have endless money, in fact most struggle financially in the early years until their products/services start to generate significant revenue to outpace expenses. So how do you keep yourself in the game and extend the chances of your business surviving? By keeping expenses as low as possible. Going remote does that for you. We spent millions annually in office rent in Lagos. That was money that could have gone into marketing or direct revenue impacting activity. If you are building/growing a business in any major African city you know office costs are a significant part of your expenses. Aside rent you are talking about utilities, furniture etc.You can take some of that saving and give your remote staff stuff like data allowances, workspace allowances etc to help them set up and work comfortably from home.If you run a company/business and thinking of going remote you can reach out and ask any questions. Iâ€™ll be glad to advise and share lessons from what weâ€™ve learnt running a remote company for 5 years now.hashtag#hiringremote hashtag#remotecompanies hashtag#businesstips hashtag#recruitingtips

Day:-8 Learning selenium with java (Automation)âœ…"Before diving into Selenium with Java, it's important to have a good understanding of Core Java topics."ğŸŒŸ What is Exception Handling?Exception handling is a way to manage errors that occur while a program is running. Instead of stopping the entire program when an error happens, exception handling lets you control what should happen when something goes wrong.ğŸŒŸ Why is it important?It helps prevent the program from crashing.It allows the program to continue running even after an error.It shows clear and friendly error messages to the user.It makes debugging and fixing issues easier.ğŸŒŸ How does it work?You write the code that might cause an error inside a special block. If an error happens, another block will handle it. This keeps the program safe and avoids unexpected crashes.ğŸŒŸ Key Terms:Try: The block where you write the code that might cause an error.Catch: The block where you handle the error if it occurs.Finally: A block that runs no matter whatâ€”whether there was an error or not.Throw: Used to create custom errors or exceptions.Throws: Used to declare exceptions that a method might cause.

Today's Learning Journey ğŸ“•: Stacks in JavaToday, I explored one of the fundamental data structuresâ€” the Stack.**What is a Stack?** A Stack is a linear data structure that follows the LIFO (Last In, First Out) principle. The last element added is the first one to be removed. Think of it like a stack of plates â€” you add to the top and remove from the top.**Why It's Important?** Stacks are used in many areas like function calls, expression evaluation, undo features in editors, and more. Understanding how they work is essential for solving real-world problems and mastering algorithms.**Key Takeaways:** 1. Core Operations: push(), pop(), peek(), and isEmpty()2. Implementation: Explored Java's built-in Stack class and also implemented it manually using arrays and linked lists. 3. Applications: Helps build intuition for recursion, backtracking, and parsing tasks.hashtag#Java hashtag#DataStructures hashtag#Stack hashtag#CodingJourney hashtag#Programming hashtag#TechLearning

Standardisation of Railway signallingThere Are in principle today 3 ways of interlocking design. 1) free wired2) object oriented3) geographicalSo what defines their adavantages and disadvantages, regading Generic and Specific applications?Engineering: nr 3) provides a high amount of Generic functionality and a little part of specific engineering. Gives the supplier more work at the start, but simplifies all over time. Rating 3-2-1 in quality. Specifying SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Testing SA changes: nr 3) needs less than 2) and far less than 1. Resposibilities: testing of SA is typically moved back to the infrastructure manager, where 1) gives a lot of work, while 3) is reduced to a functional level. Bane NOR have chosen 3) to get a high amount of Generic functionality and Standardised Engineering for its National ERTMS L2 system, due to the totality of deliveries. Based on our experience this is the right way to go to limit amount of work and to maximise the level of standardisation of functionality throughout the network, and limits all local variants of today.

The LAYER approach bridges the gap between abstract MITRE ATT&CK concepts and specific threat hunting procedures. This practical implementation shows how to analyze BlackBasta's EDR bypass techniques through multiple perspectives:â€¢ Demonstrates how to map EDR bypass tools (like Aukill) from API functions to implementation patterns to operational objectivesâ€¢ Categorizes EDR neutralization techniques into 5 buckets: BYOVD, PPL modification, telemetry disruption, unhooking/patching, and syscall techniquesâ€¢ Reveals practical hunting opportunities like monitoring driver loads, process termination clusters, and WEF filter eventsâ€¢ Improves threat hunting precision by understanding adversary operations at multiple technical levelsâ€¢ Enhances detection engineering by mapping specific implementations to MITRE TTPs with greater accuracyThreat hunting isn't just finding needles in haystacks - it's understanding the nature of both to predict future attacks.

Simulink Code Generation Optimization::--Learn to control and optimize how Simulink handles block parameters during code generationâ€”improving efficiency, flexibility, and performance in your generated code.Default Parameter Behaviour (Inlined or Tunable) - This settings controls how numeric block parameters (e.g., constants in Gain blocks) are handled in the generated code.1. Inlined (default for ERT (embedded real time) targets):--Embeds literal numeric values directly in code (means the numbers are hardcoded instead of being defined as variables or parameters. In Simulink (or programming in general), this means typing values like 5, 3.14, or [1 2 3] directly into block parameters)--Pros: Reduces RAM usage, improves execution speed.--Cons: Parameters are not tunable/calibratable post-code generation.--Required for: Models using Embedded CoderÂ® with service interface configurations. (In Embedded Coder, a service interface configuration is a way to generate code that connects your Simulink model to external application softwareâ€”like AUTOSAR components, real-time operating systems (RTOS), or custom embedded systems.)2. Tunable (default for GRT (Generic real time) targets):--Stores parameters in a global structure (can be modified/calibrated post-generation).--Pros: Allows parameter tuning (e.g., for calibration).--Cons: Uses more RAM, slightly slower.hashtag#Simulink hashtag#EmbeddedCoder hashtag#ModelBasedDesign hashtag#CodeGeneration hashtag#MATLAB hashtag#EmbeddedSystems hashtag#ControlSystems hashtag#EngineeringTools hashtag#CCodeFromSimulink hashtag#TechDocumentation hashtag#electricvehicles

Happy Monday! In the latest blog post by gdotv - Graph Database Client & Visualization Tooling, we can see an interesting Kuzu graph of past talks and events by Connected Data London, as part of the "Connected Data Knowledge Graph Challenge" (CDKG). As you'll see, the graph that's stored in a Kuzu database can be visualized effectively and effortlessly by G.V()! Blog post: https://lnkd.in/gmTZ-ZFEWhy Kuzu? The blog describes how Kuzu is built for speed, and how you can feel it when using it with G.V(). "Queries finish running faster than you can blink. Weâ€™ve sampled quite a few datasets and tried path queries of up to 30 hops, all running at milliseconds scale."âœ… The CDKG graph has the following schema:  Speakers give talks, which have keyword tags (topic of the talk). Each talk is from a past event, and belongs to a particular category.âœ… The power of graph visualization is clear with G.V(). The first image attached shows multiple layouts. The default mode is a "force-directed" layout, which shows clusters of speakers and talk topic keywords around a particular event.âœ… The other image shows a tree layout, where it's immediately obvious, at a glance, which speakers spoke at both events, and which categories have the most talks. The different layouts each showcase different aspects about the data, making it a breeze to explore the data visually for insights.We think Kuzu and G.V() can help you discover many more insights on your own data! Let me introduce you to Hidden Classes, a lesser-known capability added in Java 15 (JEP 371). These are dynamically generated classes that remain invisible to the outside world, meaning theyâ€™re not accessible via standard class loaders. Why Are They Cool?If youâ€™ve worked with frameworks like Spring, Hibernate, or tools relying on dynamic proxies, youâ€™ve likely encountered classes created on the fly. Hidden Classes take this to the next level by allowing frameworks to generate classes at runtime that are:Secure: They canâ€™t be accessed directly outside their defining context.Efficient: They reduce memory overhead by avoiding unnecessary class loading.Clean: They keep the JVMâ€™s namespace tidy by staying hidden.This makes them perfect for:Dynamic Proxy GenerationÂ (e.g., Spring AOP or mock libraries like Mockito).ORM FrameworksÂ (e.g., Hibernate generating proxies for lazy-loaded entities).Reflection-based ToolsÂ (e.g., libraries creating helper classes at runtime).Fun fact: Hibernate has been leveraging Hidden Classes in newer versions to optimize proxy generation, reducing memory footprint for large-scale apps!Why Are They Cool?Hidden Classes shine in performance and security. By keeping dynamically generated classes out of the standard class loader, they prevent accidental (or malicious) access. Plus, theyâ€™re lightweight, which is a win for applications generating thousands of proxies, like a busy Spring Boot app handling millions of requests.Thereâ€™s a catch, though: Hidden Classes are tied to a single JVM instance. You canâ€™t serialize or persist them, so theyâ€™re best for transient, runtime-only tasks.As an example:We use defineHiddenClass (introduced in Java 15) to create a class thatâ€™s hidden from standard class loaders. In real projects, youâ€™d generate bytecode with libraries like ASM or ByteBuddy, which are popular for creating dynamic classes (e.g., Hibernate uses similar techniques for entity proxies).hashtag#Java hashtag#HiddenClasses hashtag#JVM hashtag#Reflection hashtag#Spring hashtag#Hibernate
